quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 1 Quiz 10
quiz.subtitle: 1.10: First Aid and Emergency Procedures in the Lab
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Emergency response and first aid protocols

questions.question: If a large amount of corrosive chemical is spilled on your clothing, which piece of safety equipment should you use immediately?
options: Eye wash station
Safety shower
Fire extinguisher
Laboratory sink
questions.explanation: The safety shower is designed to drench the body and dilute/wash away large chemical spills on the skin or clothing.

questions.question: What is the 'P.A.S.S.' acronym used for in the laboratory?
options: Passing a lab safety inspection.
Operating a fire extinguisher.
Responding to a chemical spill.
Evaluating a scientific hypothesis.
questions.explanation: P.A.S.S. stands for Pull (the pin), Aim (at the base), Squeeze (the handle), and Sweep (side to side).

questions.question: What should you do immediately if your lab partner's clothing catches fire?
options: Run to find a teacher.
Wrap them in a fire blanket or use the 'stop, drop, and roll' method.
Spray them with a fire extinguisher.
Push them toward the safety shower.
questions.explanation: A fire blanket smothers the flames. You should avoid using a fire extinguisher directly on a person due to potential skin and lung irritation.

questions.question: If you accidentally cut your finger on broken glass in the lab, what is the first step you should take?
options: Apply a bandage yourself.
Wash the cut with soap and water and notify the instructor immediately.
Continue the experiment to avoid wasting time.
Discard the broken glass in the regular trash.
questions.explanation: All injuries, no matter how small, must be reported to the instructor after initial first aid is applied.

questions.question: A small fire starts in a beaker on your lab bench. What is the safest way to extinguish it?
options: Blow on it until it goes out.
Cover the beaker with a watch glass or a larger beaker to cut off oxygen.
Pour water into the beaker immediately.
Run out of the room to pull the fire alarm.
questions.explanation: Smothering a small, contained fire is the safest method. Adding water can cause some chemical fires to splash or intensify.

questions.question: When an evacuation alarm sounds, what should be done with gas burners and electrical equipment?
options: Leave them on to maintain the experiment.
Turn them all off before exiting the lab.
Only turn them off if you are the last person out.
Hide them under the desk.
questions.explanation: Turning off heat and power sources prevents the emergency from escalating into a fire while the room is unoccupied.

questions.question: Where can you find the location of the nearest fire extinguisher and exit route?
options: On the lab's safety map/poster.
Inside the chemical storage room.
On the back of your textbook.
By asking the principal.
questions.explanation: Every lab is required to have a clearly posted map showing the location of safety equipment and exit paths.

questions.question: If you feel dizzy or faint while working with chemicals in a fume hood, you should:
options: Lean against the hood for support.
Leave the area and get fresh air immediately, notifying your instructor.
Close your eyes and wait for it to pass.
Drink some water at the lab bench.
questions.explanation: Dizziness can be a sign of vapor inhalation; getting to fresh air is the priority.

questions.question: Why is it important to know the difference between a Class A and Class B fire extinguisher?
options: They are different colors.
Using the wrong type (like water on a grease fire) can be dangerous.
One is much heavier than the other.
Only teachers are allowed to use Class B.
questions.explanation: Different fires (wood vs. chemical vs. electrical) require different extinguishing agents to be put out safely.

questions.question: True or False: In an emergency, it is okay to leave the lab without telling anyone as long as you are safe.
options: True
False
questions.explanation: False. You must follow the designated evacuation procedure so that the instructor can account for every student during a head count.
